item.title: Girls Aloud star Sarah Harding dies aged 39
item.description: Her mother describes the singer, who had breast cancer, as a "bright, shining star".

item.title: Covid-19: Vaccine passports to start in England this month
item.description: The scheme for nightclubs and other venues from the end of September aims to ensure they stay open.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'Everyone got it wrong' on Taliban takeover - armed forces chief
item.description: Gen Sir Nick Carter says the speed of the Taliban's takeover of Afghanistan surprised the UK.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban accused of killing female police officer
item.description: The killing comes amid increasing reports of escalating repression of women in Afghanistan.

item.title: Claudia Lawrence: Police end Sand Hutton lake search
item.description: Nothing significant was found during a new search for clues to the chef's disappearance, police say.

item.title: Michael Fawcett: Charles' former aide steps down over honour claims
item.description: Michael Fawcett has been accused of offering to help a wealthy Saudi businessman receive a CBE.

item.title: Social care: Plans for reform in England likely this week - sources
item.description: Government talks are continuing through the weekend, following reports of a National Insurance hike.

item.title: Belarus 2-3 Wales: Gareth Bale scores hat-trick in World Cup qualifier
item.description: Gareth Bale scores a match-winning hat-trick to save Wales from an embarrassing defeat against Belarus and keep alive their hopes of qualifying for the World Cup.

item.title: Ikea struggles with supply problems due to driver shortage
item.description: The furniture giant is among businesses struggling with a driver shortage due to Covid and Brexit.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Great Britain 'rewrote the history books' in Japan
item.description: Great Britain's Paralympics team has "rewritten the history books" with their performance in Tokyo, says chef de mission Penny Briscoe.

item.title: South Africa's ex-president Zuma placed on medical parole
item.description: Jacob Zuma will now serve the remainder of his 15-month sentence in the community.

item.title: Moment boy cuts ribbon too soon at opening ceremony in Turkey
item.description: Turkey's president joked with the boy when he noticed he had jumped the gun at an opening ceremony.

item.title: 'I hid my litter picker in my suitcase'
item.description: Jenny I'Anson, 73, says she can spend up to five hours a day clearing rubbish.

item.title: NHS wait times: 'Iâ€™m not half the man I was'
item.description: Wayne Dennis, 50, has been waiting more than two years for treatment to his gallbladder.

item.title: New Zealand cinema worker left red-faced after voicemail blooper
item.description: A cinema employee in New Zealand went viral on TikTok with his attempt to leave a voicemail recording.

item.title: Back to school: How are pupils being kept Covid-safe?
item.description: Many children are returning to school after the holidays, while Scottish pupils already returned.

item.title: Why does Alfred Wainwright still loom large over the Lake District?
item.description: Alfred Wainwright remains synonymous with the Lake District, but why is the connection so enduring?

item.title: Covid: What do parents think about vaccinating children?
item.description: Parents share their thoughts on the prospect of offering Covid vaccines to all 12 to 15-year-olds.

item.title: Bike crashes through driver's windscreen on M9 at West Lothian
item.description: The driver of a Ford Focus had a lucky escape after the bike broke free from another car as she drove through West Lothian.

item.title: Pride march returns to Glasgow after Covid pause
item.description: Participants, dressed in bright colours, were asked to take a lateral flow test before the event and wear masks.

item.title: Sarah Harding: Remembering the Girls Aloud star's life and career
item.description: The late singer was an irrepressible and immensely likeable pop star with a "wild child" reputation.

item.title: Paralympics: â€˜We the disabled community are here to stayâ€™
item.description: Four champions share their glory and their pain from the 16th Paralympic Games in Tokyo.

item.title: Why Scotland and Yorkshire are TV's top UK destinations
item.description: There's been a glut of shows featuring stunning scenery, simple lifestyles and down-to-earth people.

item.title: 'I studied law in jail - now I want to change the system'
item.description: LaTonya Myers spent nine months in jail because she couldnâ€™t afford bail - now she's helping others facing the same challenge.

item.title: Hamid Nouri: How Sweden arrested a suspected Iranian war criminal
item.description: Prosecutors have put Hamid Nouri on trial over a 1988 massacre in Iran. This is how they did it.

item.title: Covid: How do I get the vaccine and will I need a booster?
item.description: A third dose is being offered to up to half a million people in the UK with weakened immune systems.

item.title: Kenyan men join battle to end FGM
item.description: Campaigners say it is important that Kenyan men join the battle to end female genital mutilation.

item.title: What's it like to be in the 1% of female lorry drivers?
item.description: The chronic shortage of lorry drivers has led haulage firms to try to attract more women to the role.

item.title: 'I've eaten the same breakfast for the last 22 years'
item.description: A veteran hotel inspector reveals the highs and lows of working undercover in Scotland.

item.title: Verstappen wins Dutch Grand Prix in front of passionate home crowd
item.description: Red Bull's Max Verstappen takes a dominant victory over Mercedes' Lewis Hamilton in the Dutch Grand Prix to retake the championship lead.

item.title: Arsenal stun defending champions Chelsea in WSL opener
item.description: Arsenal impress at the Emirates Stadium as they secure victory over defending champions Chelsea in their Women's Super League opener.

item.title: England v India: Moeen Ali misses run-out chance as England hopes fade
item.description: Moeen Ali misses a gilt-edged run-out chance following a mix-up between India batsmen Rishabh Pant and Shardul Thakur as England's chances fade in the fourth Test at The Oval.

item.title: Solheim Cup: US awarded putt after ball picked up too early
item.description: US star Nelly Korda is awarded a hole-winning eagle putt after Europe's Madelene Sagstrom picks up the ball by the hole before the 10 seconds stated in the rules had elapsed.

item.title: Afghanistan: What's life like since the Taliban took over?
item.description: People around the country tell the BBC they have lost basic freedoms and are struggling to survive.

item.title: Afghanistan: Despair of Brits and UK allies stuck behind Taliban lines
item.description: An NHS worker, a teacher and families trapped in Afghanistan tell the BBC about their plans now.

item.title: Afghanistan women's cricket team: Players hiding in Kabul fear Taliban rule
item.description: Members of Afghanistan's women's cricket team are hiding in Kabul, fearing for their safety following the Taliban's return to power.

item.title: British soldier describes caring for Kabul airport baby
item.description: Lt Col Ben Caesar helped look after the baby who was pulled over the airport wall in Afghanistan.

item.title: Life under the Taliban: Where is your male escort?
item.description: Lyse Doucet takes the temperature on the streets of the Afghan capital as the Taliban tighten their grip.

item.title: Kabul drone strike: The key questions about a US attack
item.description: Ten Afghan civilians died when the US targeted a vehicle it says was linked to an imminent bombing.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban parade captured equipment in Kandahar
item.description: The militant group showcased the kit captured during their takeover of Afghanistan.

item.title: Kabul make-up artist: 'Women like me are Taliban targets'
item.description: A make-up artist in hiding explains how much Afghanistan's beauty industry has meant to women.

item.title: Afghanistan: How many asylum seekers has the UK taken in?
item.description: The UK government says it will resettle up to 20,000 Afghan refugees, but warns it will 'take time'.

item.title: Afghanistan: Joe Biden speech on withdrawal fact-checked
item.description: How consistent is President Biden in his comments on Afghanistan following the final US troop withdrawal?

item.title: Afghanistan: How can the West stop terror bases?
item.description: The foreign secretary says the UK will fight ISIS-K by all means available - but what does that mean?

item.title: Afghanistan: Rescued animals 'in amazing condition' in UK
item.description: Most of the 150 animals rescued by "Pen" Farthing's charity are to be adopted by veterans.

item.title: Amid violent reprisals, Afghans fear the Taliban's 'amnesty' was empty
item.description: Reports suggest the Taliban are searching for, and allegedly killing, people they pledged to leave in peace.

item.title: Female journalist who interviewed Taliban flees
item.description: Beheshta Arghand, who made headlines when she interviewed the Taliban, has spoken out after fleeing the country.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'Struggle to survive or race to escape' on streets of Kabul
item.description: The BBC's Lyse Doucet reports from the Afghan capital, a day after the last US troops left.

item.title: Afghanistan: UK embassy told Afghans to go to Abbey Gate before suicide attack
item.description: Despite an attack being expected, emails seen by the BBC show embassy staff directing Afghans to the gate.

item.title: Taliban are back - what next for Afghanistan?
item.description: As the Taliban take power after 20 years of conflict, what did the war achieve and what happens now?

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Great Britain finish Games with two more bronze medals
item.description: Great Britain win two bronze medals on the final day of the Tokyo Paralympics to finish second in the medal table.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics medal table - which country won most golds?
item.description: Which country topped the medal table at the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics? How did Great Britain get on?

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Who are Great Britain's medal winners?
item.description: A list of the Great Britain medal winners from the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Hannah Cockroft & Aled Sion Davies retain titles for GB
item.description: British athletes Hannah Cockroft and Aled Sion Davies retain their Paralympic titles, as canoeists Charlotte Henshaw and Laura Sugar also triumph on day 11 in Tokyo.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: The Paralympic dream that started at the supermarket
item.description: Aruba had never had a Paralympic team until a student in her 20s decided to make it happen.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: What you need to know about Paralympic classification
item.description: From KL1 to PT2 and F11 to SB6 - everything you need to know about classification at the Paralympic Games.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Great Britain win three golds and pass 100-medal mark
item.description: Great Britain win three more golds on day 10 and pass the 100-medal mark at the Tokyo Paralympics.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Sport-by-sport guide
item.description: Twenty-two sports will feature in the Tokyo Paralympics - find out more about them all here.

item.title: Sarah Storey says her 17th Paralympic gold 'feels like an out of body experience'
item.description: Britain's Sarah Storey says she "feels immensely proud" to have won a record 17 Paralympic gold medals and is hoping to add more at Paris 2024.

item.title: Shot putter stripped of gold - for being three minutes late
item.description: Muhammad Ziyad Zolkefli won his shot put event but had his title revoked because he was three minutes late.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Afghanistan athlete Hossain Rasouli makes debut after evacuation
item.description: Afghanistan evacuee Hossain Rasouli finally gets his chance to compete at the Tokyo Paralympics - and his opponents can't "help but feel joy".

item.title: Afghanistan: Shukria Barakzai's whispered voice notes and dramatic escape
item.description: The desperate messages sent by Afghan politician Shukria Barakzai to a UK MP as the Taliban tried to hunt her down.

item.title: Afghanistan: The 'undefeated' Panjshir Valley - an hour from Kabul
item.description: The Panjshir Valley has been a flashpoint in Afghanistan's turbulent history - now it's happening again.

item.title: Bilal Sarwary: 'The plane hit the tower and all our lives changed'
item.description: Afghan journalist Bilal Sarwary was selling carpets when 9/11 happened. From that day on, everything changed.

item.title: Shot in the head in Angola, left for dead, now a Wetherspoons star
item.description: Cesar Kimbirima fled Angola after being shot four times and spending five months in a coma.

item.title: Michael Knighton: The man who could have bought Man Utd for Â£10m but walked away
item.description: In August 1989, Michael Knighton celebrated his Manchester United takeover deal at Old Trafford. But the plotting against him had just begun.
